bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, July 1, 1953

div1.p: Truby comments on the financial records from Camp Lazear, which Hench had sent to him.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, July 1, 1953
div1.opener:
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California.
July 1, 1953
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Here is a simple letter of transmittal of that “puzzle” you so
kindly put up to me. I have enjoyed this work very much for it
made me get busy and study, and I have learned more out of the
old Senate Document than every.

I am enclosing some of Tate's letters with this so that you can
read his slant on my production. I hope it pleases you, but as
I have said in one of my letters enclosed herewith, you can change
this analysis of the story, in whole or in part, as you see fit.
I have gone in to detail at times in order that everyone might
understand the conditions thoroughly enough to appreciate my
views on the matters discussed. I told Tate that possibly I had
overplayed the checkbook notes. To me, it was quite remarkable
to dig into (after fifty years) the things that happened at the
Camp.

Tate dwells quite at length on the importance of “Martinez”. I,
of course, knew nothing about him, but I have learned enough
about him in digging into the Senate Document, to realize that
he really was quite a favorite of Reed's. Whether Martinez was
his middle name or not I do not know. As I have stated in the
story, I could not find the name of Jose Fernandez anywhere in
any of the books I have on the subject. I don't believe you will
find it in the Senate Document - I failed to do so. But, what
does it matter as long as we are giving Martinez (even though
Martinez in his middle name) the credit for what that individual
did?

The checkbook went off to you on June 24th by First Class Mail,
Registered. I should have reached you by now. I hope it gets to
you in good shape.

I have worked under considerable difficulties - first one thing
after another, including physical therapy and the other things
have to do although I have developed many of my muscles which had
been washed out from my neck to my toes. I couldn't have done this
at all if it hadn't been for my daughter's help.

Now, I am confronted with another thing which will bother me. Now
that rent control is off, no one can tell how high rents will go.
Of course, retired Army officers have a limit. However, I am not
too hopeful that our landlord will be any too easy on an Army officer.
I will let you know later how it turns out.

With this I think I had better sign off with the hope that this
story will not reveal my age! I am going to have another birthday
this month. Best wishes to you and yours,
